conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to calculate the change in the magnetic flux through the coil as it rotates 60° downward around the z-axis.

The magnetic flux Φ is given by Φ = B · A · cos(θ), where B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the coil, and θ is the angle between the normal to the plane of the coil and the direction of the magnetic field.
The coil ABCO is shown in the xz-plane, with the magnetic field direction along the positive x-axis.
The initial angle θ_initial = 0° because the coil is in the xz-plane, and the normal to the coil is aligned with the magnetic field direction.
The initial magnetic flux is Φ_initial = B · A · cos(0°) = 0.1 T · 0.4 m² · 1 = 0.04 Wb.
The final angle θ_final = 60° because the coil is rotated 60° downward.
The final magnetic flux is Φ_final = B · A · cos(60°) = 0.1 T · 0.4 m² · 1/2 = 0.02 Wb.
The change in magnetic flux is ΔΦ = Φ_final - Φ_initial = 0.02 Wb - 0.04 Wb = -0.02 Wb.
The change in the magnetic flux passing through the coil is -0.02 Weber.
